verses.text: Praise be to the LORD my Rock, who trains my hands for war, my fingers for battle.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 144 This psalm is set in the midst of conflict (v. 11), but the speaker does not panic as he calls upon the Lord to appear. The language of God’s appearance is similar to Ps. 18, also by David. The language of battle applies figuratively to the spiritual warfare that Christians wage against the “spiritual forces of evil” (Eph. 6:10–20).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:1
rsbNotes.text:
144:1 my rock. See notes Ps. 62:2; cf. Ps. 28:7; Deut. 32:18; Ex. 17:6.

who trains my hands for war. The association of God with warfare can be a stumbling block in appreciating the Old Testament. There is no conflict between the Old and New Testaments on this point. The warfare of God’s people has been heightened and intensified for Christians, whose war is against unseen spiritual enemies arrayed against God and themselves for His sake (Eph. 6:10–20).

verses.text: He is my loving God and my fortress, my stronghold and my deliverer, my shield, in whom I take refuge, who subdues peoples under me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:2
rsbNotes.text:
144:2 steadfast love . . . fortress. The Bible presents no conflict between God’s love and His warfare.

under me. David and later faithful kings.

verses.text: O LORD, what is man that you care for him, the son of man that you think of him?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:3
rsbNotes.text: 144:3 what is man. See Ps. 8:4.

verses.text: Man is like a breath; his days are like a fleeting shadow.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:4
rsbNotes.text: 144:4 like a breath. Ephemeral and short-lived. The word is translated “vanity” in Eccl. 1:2. The poet is amazed that God cares for him.

verses.text: Part your heavens, O LORD, and come down; touch the mountains, so that they smoke.
Send forth lightning and scatter {the enemies}; shoot your arrows and rout them.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:5
rsbNotes.text: 144:5 so that they smoke. When God appears, nature trembles before Him (Ex. 19:16–19).

verses.text: Reach down your hand from on high; deliver me and rescue me from the mighty waters, from the hands of foreigners
whose mouths are full of lies, whose right hands are deceitful.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:7
rsbNotes.text: 144:7 many waters. The enemies are compared to the Near Eastern popular conception of the cosmic waters of chaos (18:4, 14 and notes).

verses.text: I will sing a new song to you, O God; on the ten-stringed lyre I will make music to you,
to the One who gives victory to kings, who delivers his servant David from the deadly sword.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:9
rsbNotes.text: 144:9 a new song. See note Ps. 33:3.

verses.text: Deliver me and rescue me from the hands of foreigners whose mouths are full of lies, whose right hands are deceitful.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:11
rsbNotes.text: 144:11 from the hand of foreigners. The threat is from outside Israel.

verses.text: Then our sons in their youth will be like well-nurtured plants, and our daughters will be like pillars carved to adorn a palace.
Our barns will be filled with every kind of provision. Our sheep will increase by thousands, by tens of thousands in our fields;

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:12
rsbNotes.text: 144:12 our sons . . . our daughters. When the oppressive foreigners have been thrown back, the next generation will flourish.

verses.text: our oxen will draw heavy loads. There will be no breaching of walls, no going into captivity, no cry of distress in our streets.
Blessed are the people of whom this is true; blessed are the people whose God is the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 144:14
rsbNotes.text: 144:14 no mishap. The poet envisions complete security from outside military threats (see text note).
